description: Presumed from up- +â€Ž shot, referring to the last shot in a match of archery.

entries.meaning: The final result, or outcome of something.
examples: I have no skill of fancy to tell of that dark collogue, but the upshot was that Alison swore by her lost soul and the pride of sin to bring the lass into thrall to her master.
I'm not interested in hearing all the details. Just give me the upshot.

entries.meaning: (US) A positive aspect or consequence, often either unexpected or in contrast to other negative aspects.
examples: One of the major upshots of prefab building is its decreased environmental impact.
